problems.title: Irreducibility of the polynomial x^3 + 2x + 1 in Z_3[x]
problems.hint: • Show that it does not have a root in $\mathbb{Z} _3$.
problems.solution: Since the polynomial is of degree $3$, it is enough to show that it does not have a root in $\mathbb{Z} _3$. Let $p(x) = x^3 + 2x + 1.$ The possible roots are $\bar{0} , \bar{1} , \bar{2} .$ Note that \begin{align*} p(\bar{0} ) & = 1 \equiv 1 \ (\mathrm{mod}\ 3)\\ p(\bar{1} ) & = 4 \equiv 1 \ (\mathrm{mod}\ 3)\\ p(\bar{2} ) & = 13 \equiv 1\ (\mathrm{mod}\ 3). \end{align*} Thus, the polynomial is irreducible over $\mathbb{Z} _3$.

problems.title: The minimal polynomial of $\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} $ over Q
problems.problem: Find the minimal polynomial of $\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} $ over $\mathbb{Q} $.
problems.hint:
• Assume $x = \sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5}$, and power $x$ to get rid of $\sqrt{3} \text{ and } \sqrt{5} $. This will give a polynomial satisfying $\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} .$
  • Now show that the polynomial is minimal.
problems.solution:
To find the minimal polynomial of $x = \sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} $ over $\mathbb{Q} $, observe that \begin{align*} x = \sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} & \implies x^2 = 8 + 2 \sqrt{15} \\ & \implies (x^2 -8)^2 = (2 \sqrt{15} )^2 \\ & \implies x^4 - 16x^2 + 64 = 60 \\ & \implies x^4 - 16x^2 + 4 = 0. \end{align*}
It is clear that the polynomial $p(x) = x^4 - 16x^2 + 4$ satisfies $\sqrt{3} + \sqrt{5} $. We only need to check that it is minimal which is equivalent to show that the polynomial is irreducible over $\mathbb{Q} $. By the rational root theorem, the possible rational roots for the polynomial $p(x)$ are $\pm 1, \pm 2$ and $\pm 4$. But, none of these satisfies $p(x)$ and $p(x)$ does not have a root in $\mathbb{Q} $.
Let us assume that $p(x)$ is reducible over $\mathbb{Q} $, that is, it can be broken into monic quadratic polynomials in $\mathbb{Q} $, say \begin{align*} & (x^2 + a x + b)(x^2 + c x + d) = x^4 - 16x^2 + 4 \\ \implies & x^4 + (a + c)x^3 + (ac + b + d)x^2 + (ad + bc) x + bd = x^4 - 16x^2 + 4. \end{align*} Comparing the coefficients, we get \begin{align*} c = -a, \quad b + d - a^2 = - 16, \quad a(d - b) = 0, \quad \text{ and } bd = 4. \end{align*} Consider $a (d - b) = 0$. Note that if $a = 0$, then we have \begin{align*} bd = 4 \text{ and } b + d = -16. \end{align*} Thus, $b$ and $d$ are roots of the quadratic equation $t^2 + 16t + 4 = 0$, which does not have are rational roots (discriminant (which is $240$) is not a square), thus $a = 0$ is not possible.

If $b - d = 0$, that is, $ b = d$, then $b^2 = 4$, so $b = \pm 2$. Also, \begin{align*} b + d - a^2 = -16 & \implies 2b - a^2 = -16 \\ & \implies a^2 = 2b + 16 = \begin{cases} 20, &\text{ if } b = 2 ;\\ 12, &\text{ if } b = -2. \end{cases} \end{align*} In any case, $a$ can not be a rational number and hence $b= d $ is also not possible. Thus, the polynomial is irreducible and hence minimal.

problems.title: NBHM - 2005 - Number of Generators of a Cyclic Group of Order 10
problems.problem:
Let $G$ be a cyclic group of order $10$. For $g \in G$, let $\left\langle g \right\rangle $ denotes the subgroup generated by $g$. How many elements are there in the set 
    \[
        \{g \in G: \left\langle g \right\rangle = G\}?
    \]
problems.hint: • If $g$ is an element of order $n$ in a group and $k \in \mathbb{N} $. Then \[ \left\langle g^k \right\rangle = \left\langle g^{\gcd (n,k)} \right\rangle \text{ and } \left\vert a^k \right\vert = \frac{n}{\gcd (n,k)}. \]
problems.solution:
We need to determine the number of elements in $G$ which generates the full group. Since the order of $G$ is $10$ and it is cyclic, if an element $g$ generates $G$, then $\gcd (o(g), 10) = 1$. This follows from the result that if $g$ is an element of order $n$ in a group and $k \in \mathbb{N} $. Then \[ \left\langle g^k \right\rangle = \left\langle g^{\gcd (n,k)} \right\rangle \text{ and } \left\vert a^k \right\vert = \frac{n}{\gcd (n,k)}. \]
So the number of elements in $G$ which generates ghe full group will by $phi(10) = 4$, where $phi$ is the Euler-Totient function.

problems.title: Circle is a subgroup of C*
problems.problem:
Let $G$ be the group of all non-zero complex numbers $x +  \iota y \ (\text{where } x, y \in \mathbb{R}) $ under multiplication. Let 
    \[
        H = \{x + \iota y \in \mathbb{C} ^* : x^2 + y^2 = 1 \} .
    \] 
    Prove that $H$ is a subgroup of $G$.
problems.hint:
• Show that $H$ is non-empty.
  • Note that if $z = x +\iota y$, then $\vert z \vert = \sqrt{x^2 + y^2} $ and $|z \cdot w| = \vert z \vert \cdot \vert w \vert $.
problems.solution:
Note that $1 + \iota 0 \in H$, so $H \neq \varnothing . $ Now to prove that it is a subgroup, we will mainly check whether it is closed under multiplication or not and closed under inversion or not.
Let $z_1 = x_1 + \iota y_1 \in H$ and $z_2 = x_2 + \iota y_2 \in H$. Then we need to show that $z \cdot w \in H$. Observe that \begin{align*} z_1 \in H \implies x_1^2 + y_1^2 = 1 \implies \vert z_1 \vert^2 = 1 \implies \vert z_1 \vert = 1 \\ z_2 \in H \implies x_2^2 + y_2^2 = 1 \implies \vert z_2 \vert^2 = 1 \implies \vert z_2 \vert = 1. \end{align*} Since $\vert z_1 \cdot z_2 \vert = \vert z_1 \vert \cdot \vert z_2 \vert $, so we have \begin{align*} \vert z_1 \cdot z_2 \vert = 1 \implies z_1 \cdot w_1 \in H. \end{align*}
For the inverse, let $z = x + \iota y \in H$. We need to show that $\frac{1}{z} \in H$, that is, $\left\vert \frac{1}{z} \right\vert = 1$. Again, note that for any complex numbers $z,w $ with $w \neq 0$, we have \begin{align*} \left\vert \frac{z}{w} \right\vert = \frac{\vert z \vert }{\vert w \vert }. \end{align*} So \[ \left\vert \frac{1}{z} \right\vert = \frac{1}{\vert z \vert } = 1 \implies \frac{1}{z} \in H. \]
Thus $H$ is a subgroup of $G$.
We can explicitly find out the inverse also. Note that \begin{align*} \frac{1}{x+ \iota y} & = \frac{1}{x + \iota y} \times \frac{x - \iota y}{x - \iota y} = \frac{x - \iota y}{x^2 + y^2} = x - \iota y. \end{align*} Since $x^2 + (-y)^2 = x^2 + y^2 = 1$, implies $x - \iota y \in H$.
